situation.description: You're a team lead and just reviewed work from a team member. The deliverable has some significant issues that need to be addressed, but the person worked hard on it and seems proud of their effort.
situation.context: This is a relatively new team member who you want to develop. They've shown potential but still have skill gaps.

variables.label: When do you give feedback?
variables.description: Choose when to deliver the feedback

result.title: Quick Fix, Potential Damage
result.description: The issues get addressed quickly, but the team member feels caught off-guard and defensive.
consequences: Team member feels embarrassed in front of others
They may become hesitant to share work early in the future
result.insight: Immediate, direct, task-focused feedback is efficient but can feel harsh. It works best when there's already high trust and psychological safety.

result.title: Development-Focused Conversation
result.description: The meeting becomes a coaching conversation where the team member discovers the issues themselves.
consequences: Takes more time than a quick correction
Team member develops critical thinking skills
They feel respected and invested in
Learning is more likely to transfer to future work
result.insight: This approach is ideal for developing team members. The time investment pays off in long-term capability building and engagement.

result.title: Mixed Signals
result.description: The delayed feedback feels disconnected from the work, and the sandwich approach obscures the key message.
consequences: Team member may not fully understand the issues
Opportunity for timely learning is lost
result.insight: Delayed feedback with softened delivery can seem kind but often fails to drive improvement. Be timely and clear, while still being respectful.

defaultOutcome.title: A Reasonable Approach
defaultOutcome.description: Your combination of choices represents a thoughtful approach to giving feedback.
consequences: Think about whether the person needs direction or discovery
Balance the immediate task needs with long-term development
defaultOutcome.insight: There's rarely one 'right' way to give feedback. The best approach depends on the person, the context, and the relationship.
